t: Job 14
Man*p that is born of a woman is of few days, and full of trouble.
He*p cometh forth like a flower, and is cut down: he fleeth also as a shadow, and continueth not.
And*p dost thou open thine eyes upon such an one, and bringest me into judgment with thee?
Who*p can bring a clean thing out of an unclean? not one.
Seeing*p his days are determined, the number of his months are with thee, thou hast appointed his bounds that he cannot pass;
Turn*p from him, that he may rest, till he shall accomplish, as an hireling, his day.
For*p there is hope of a tree, if it be cut down, that it will sprout again, and that the tender branch thereof will not cease.
Though*p the root thereof wax old in the earth, and the stock thereof die in the ground;
Yet*p through the scent of water it will bud, and bring forth boughs like a plant.
But*p man dieth, and wasteth away: yea, man giveth up the ghost, and where is he?
As*p the waters fail from the sea, and the flood decayeth and drieth up:
So*p man lieth down, and riseth not: till the heavens be no more, they shall not awake, nor be raised out of their sleep.
O*p that thou wouldest hide me in the grave, that thou wouldest keep me secret, until thy wrath be past, that thou wouldest appoint me a set time, and remember me!
If*p a man die, shall he live again? all the days of my appointed time will I wait, till my change come.
Thou*p shalt call, and I will answer thee: thou wilt have a desire to the work of thine hands.
For*p now thou numberest my steps: dost thou not watch over my sin?
My*p transgression is sealed up in a bag, and thou sewest up mine iniquity.
And*p surely the mountain falling cometh to nought, and the rock is removed out of his place.
The*p waters wear the stones: thou washest away the things which grow out of the dust of the earth; and thou destroyest the hope of man.
Thou*p prevailest for ever against him, and he passeth: thou changest his countenance, and sendest him away.
His*p sons come to honour, and he knoweth it not; and they are brought low, but he perceiveth it not of them.
But*p his flesh upon him shall have pain, and his soul within him shall mourn.
